channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 The New York Times Company

item.title: An American Team Went to Combat Haiti’s Gangs, Then Lost Two of Its Own
item.description: A Haitian American Navy veteran and his police officer cousin who were working in Haiti with Studebaker, an American military contractor, are missing and presumed dead.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles, David C. Adams and André Paultre
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: India Will Buy Russian Oil Despite Trump’s Threats, Officials Say
item.description: President Trump said last week that he would punish India if it did not cut off Russian oil imports, but he did not specify what the penalty might be.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal and Hari Kumar
item.media:description: An oil refinery in Guwahati, India, in 2023. Russia is the source of more than one third of India’s oil imports.

item.title: Mike Huckabee, Israel’s Passionate Defender as Gaza War Drives Allies Away
item.description: Mr. Huckabee, a Baptist minister, is the first evangelical to serve as American ambassador to Israel. Christian conservatives and the Netanyahu government are pleased.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Bumiller
item.category: International Fellowship of Christians and Jews
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mike Huckabee, the U.S. ambassador to Israel, on Tuesday at his official residence in Jerusalem.

item.title: Protesters in Thailand Denounce Prime Minister After Clashes With Cambodia
item.description: Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra of Thailand had already been suspended after a leaked phone call that many say showed her selling out her country.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Muktita Suhartono
item.media:description: A rally in Bangkok on Saturday calling for the resignation of Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra of Thailand.

item.title: Photos From a Gaza Airdrop
item.description: A photographer accompanied a Jordanian aircrew as it dropped aid to Gaza, where starvation is rising.
item.dc:creator: Diego Ibarra Sanchez and Eric Nagourney
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A devastated Gaza, as seen from a Jordanian Air Force Hercules during a coordinated aid drop by Jordan and the United Arab Emirates, delivering 18 tons of food and basic necessities.

item.title: Iran Is Holding at Least 4 US Citizens, Rights Groups and Families Say
item.description: Two were seized after Israel and the United States attacked Iranian targets in June, and two others have been held since 2024.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: An anti-American mural in Tehran this spring.

item.title: U.S. Victims of Hamas and Hezbollah Attacks Sue UNRWA
item.description: Relatives of people killed in terrorist attacks accuse the agency that aids Palestinians of providing support to the armed groups.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.category: United Nations Relief and Works Agency
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: American citizens living in Israel and the United States filed a lawsuit accusing UNRWA of providing support to Hamas and Hezbollah.

item.title: A Bid to Undo a Colonial-Era Wrong Touches a People’s Old Wounds
item.description: An Oxford museum’s collection of objects taken from the Naga people includes human remains. What to do with them now is not a simple matter.
item.dc:creator: Pragati K.B.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of a Naga delegation visited the Pitt Rivers Museum in Oxford, England, in June.

item.title: Fleeing Domestic Violence, and the Russian Advance
item.description: “I wanted something decent,” said a woman at a shelter near Ukraine’s border with Russia. “But this is how it turned out.”
item.dc:creator: Kim Barker, Sara Cincurova and Oksana Parafeniuk
item.media:credit: Oksana Parafeniuk for The New York Times

item.title: El Salvador Ends Term Limits, Letting Bukele Seek Re-Election Indefinitely
item.description: President Nayib Bukele has cracked down on gangs and civil rights, jailing tens of thousands of people. The National Assembly also extended the presidential term to six years.
item.dc:creator: Francesca Regalado, Annie Correal and Alan Yuhas
item.media:description: President Nayib Bukele of El Salvador at the White House in April.

item.title: Trump Envoy Witkoff Visits Gaza as Aid Crisis Deepens
item.description: Steve Witkoff went to the Palestinian enclave amid growing pressure on Israel to ease a deepening hunger crisis there. Hamas derided the visit as a “propaganda show.”
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon
item.media:credit: Maansi Srivastava for The New York Times

item.title: In Delhi and New York, Hindu Right Wing Lines Up Against Mamdani
item.description: As Zohran Mamdani gets within striking distance of becoming New York’s first Muslim mayor, he is drawing fire from supporters of India’s populist prime minister, who accuse him of being anti-Hindu.
item.dc:creator: Pranav Baskar
item.media:credit: Andres Kudacki for The New York Times
item.media:description: Some Hindu American groups accuse Zohran Mamdani, seen here addressing a group of Muslim men in March, of promoting an anti-Hindu agenda.

item.title: How the Threat of Trump’s Highest Tariff Derailed an African Nation
item.description: The president backed off his call for a 50 percent tariff on Lesotho, imposing 15 percent instead. But in a country where most people live hand-to-mouth, the damage was already done.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon and Joao Silva

item.title: A Letter to the Future
item.description: Writing yourself a letter is a good way to identify the things in your life that matter — as well as those things that you can let go.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: What Do Trump’s Tariff Hikes Mean for Canada’s Trade-Dependent Economy?
item.description: After Canada failed to strike a trade deal with Washington, the president raised tariffs on some Canadian exports this week.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Tiff Macklem, the governor of the Bank of Canada, said that tariffs on cars, steel and aluminum were “having a very direct, severe effect” on some industries.

item.title: SpaceX, NASA Launch Astronauts to Space Station as Clouds Stay Just Far Enough Away
item.description: After a scrubbed launch on Thursday, four astronauts lifted off from Florida and will dock at the International Space Station on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang
item.media:description: A SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket launching on Friday. It was carrying NASA’s Crew-11 astronauts to the International Space Station.

item.title: Trump Turns to Untested Tariffs to Reorder Global Trade
item.description: President Trump has long wanted to rework world trade. The tariffs set to go into effect next week will carry out that plan.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Alyssa Schukar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Economists remain skeptical that President Trump’s approach to tariffs will work as he intends.

item.title: Putin Blames Frustration Over Ukraine Talks on ‘Inflated Expectations’
item.description: The Russian president didn’t directly respond to President Trump’s ultimatum that Moscow halt its offensive by the end of next week or face financial penalties.
item.dc:creator: Nataliya Vasilyeva and Paul Sonne
item.media:description: Ukrainian firefighters in the courtyard of a tuberculosis hospital after a Russian bomb struck its roof in Kharkiv, Ukraine, in July.

item.title: Why Trump’s Tariffs Are Closing Factories in Lesotho
item.description: The closure of a factory in the small southern African nation of Lesotho is an early effect of the global disruption caused by President Trump’s tariffs. John Eligon, the Johannesburg bureau chief for The New York Times, talks with Katrin Bennhold, a senior writer, about what he has seen there.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon, Katrin Bennhold, Christina Thornell, Joao Silva, Nikolay Nikolov and Laura Salaberry

item.title: Derk Sauer, Champion of Free Press in a New Russia, Dies at 72
item.description: He earned a media fortune in 1990s Russia with a “sex, news and rock ’n’ roll” strategy and defended press freedoms after the industry became beleaguered and unprofitable.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Claire Moses
item.media:description: Derk Sauer in the Netherlands last year. After Russia invaded Ukraine, he became a champion of Russian journalists who had fled to escape repression.

item.title: Corruption Scandal Puts Mexico’s President on Defense Against Trump
item.description: Mexico’s president, battling U.S. accusations that the cartels have gripped her government, is facing a scandal in which two former officials are on the run and their old boss is now a top senator.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib and Paulina Villegas
item.media:description: Adán Augusto López Hernández when he was Mexico’s interior minister. He is at the center of a scandal around men he appointed to security positions in Tabasco State when he was governor.

item.title: At Least 1 Dead and 5 Missing After Mine Collapse in Chile
item.description: Chile’s state-owned copper company halted operations at its El Teniente mine after an earthquake.
item.dc:creator: Francesca Regalado and Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:description: At least one person was killed and five are missing at Codelco’s El Teniente copper mine in Chile.

item.title: Trump Gives Mexico a Reprieve but Slams Canada With Higher Tariffs
item.description: The imbalance in President Trump’s treatment of America’s closest trading partners may come from his desire to make Canada the 51st state, some Canadians believe.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: In June, when Prime Minister Mark Carney of Canada hosted a Group of 7 meeting, he announced that he had an agreement to reach a trade deal with Mr. Trump by July 21. It didn’t materialize.

item.title: Friday Briefing: Trump’s Tariff Day
item.description: Plus, our art critic shares his favorite places in Rome.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: A port in Tampa, Fla.

item.title: E.U. Did Not Retain Texts Sought by Journalists on Covid Vaccine Deal
item.description: The European Union acknowledged for the first time that a top official reviewed the messages, but said it had no duty to keep them, despite intense interest.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek
item.media:description: Ursula von der Leyen, the president of the European Commission, in London, in March.

item.title: A French Beach Town’s Plea to Tourists: Keep Your Clothes On
item.description: “A little restraint, please!” wrote the mayor of Les Sables d’Olonne, who is leading an effort to stop visitors from wandering the town in just their swimwear.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:description: La Grande Plage, the beach in Les Sables d’Olonne, France, in 2021. The town fines tourists who venture beyond the sand in their swimsuits.

item.title: Cécile Dionne, Who Found Fame and Despair as a Quintuplet, Dies at 91
item.description: The Dionnes, the first quints known to have survived infancy, became a global sensation and prey for the greedy. And Cécile came to resent it all. Only one of the five now survives.
item.dc:creator: Jane Gross

item.title: Arab States Call for Hamas to Disarm Amid Push for a Palestinian State
item.description: “Hamas must end its rule in Gaza,” reads a declaration endorsed by the 22 member nations of the Arab League.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: The surprise move, in a declaration endorsed on Tuesday by the 22 member nations of the Arab League, also condemned Hamas’s Oct. 7 attacks on Israel, which set off the devastating war in Gaza.

item.title: Here’s What to Know About Trump’s 50% Tariffs on Brazil
item.description: Latin America’s biggest economy can weather the shock of a high tariff rate. But American coffee lovers and Brazilian ranchers are likely to feel the pain.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Workers stockpiled coffee bean bags in Vila Valerio, northern Espírito Santo, Brazil in July. Brazil is the world’s biggest exporter of coffee beans and a major supplier to the U.S. market.

item.title: Friday Briefing: Trump’s Tariff Day
item.description: Plus, our critic’s favorite art places in Rome.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: A port in Tampa, Fla.

item.title: Dozens Killed in Protests Over Gas Prices in Angola
item.description: Outraged residents took to the streets of the southern African nation when a taxi strike descended into chaos.
item.dc:creator: Gilberto Neto and John Eligon
item.media:description: A burned vehicle in Luanda, Angola, during a general strike against rising fuel prices on Tuesday.

item.title: ISIS Militant Sentenced to Life for Role in Burning Pilot Alive in Syria
item.description: Osama Krayem, a Swedish citizen, was found guilty in Stockholm of a war crime. He had already been convicted of terrorist attacks in Paris and Brussels.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: Stockholm District Court in 2024. Though Osama Krayem denied any wrongdoing, video evidence showed him participating in the gruesome murder of First Lt. Moaz al-Kasasbeh in 2015.

item.title: A Short History of Awkward Gift Giving Between U.S. and U.K. Leaders
item.description: For foreign leaders seeking to woo President Trump, a thoughtful gift is a time-honored diplomatic tactic. But there are pitfalls.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump and Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain in Aberdeen, Scotland, on Monday. On the visit, Scotland’s first minister, John Swinney, presented Mr. Trump with gifts including a document dating from 1853 that registered the marriage of Mr. Trump’s maternal great-grandparents.

item.title: Lithuania’s Prime Minister Steps Down
item.description: Prime Minister Gintautas Paluckas’s business dealings are under investigation by Lithuanian authorities.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel and Tomas Dapkus
item.media:description: Prime Minister Gintautas Paluckas speaking at a news conference in February.

item.title: Major Study on Transgender Youth Health Care to Begin in U.K.
item.description: Researchers at King’s College London will track the experiences of up to 3,000 children and teenagers who are being treated by Britain’s health service.
item.dc:creator: Chloe W. Shakin
item.media:description: King’s College London, one of the leading research institutions in Britain, has received government funding to carry out a long-term study into gender care for young people.

item.title: Trump Taps Climate Skeptics to Attack Science on Global Warming
item.description: The agency asked five climate skeptics to write a report criticizing the consensus on global warming. Scientists are pointing out its errors.
item.dc:creator: Maxine Joselow and Brad Plumer
item.media:description: The Department of Energy in Washington, D.C.

item.title: A New Border Wall in Arizona Would Block a Key Wildlife Corridor
item.description: The barrier, in a remote part of Arizona, would threaten one of the most important remaining animal migration routes on the state’s southern border, according to a new report.
item.dc:creator: Douglas Main

item.title: Ancient Gems Linked to Buddha Are Returned to India
item.description: Sotheby’s had canceled an auction of the Piprahwa Gems after pressure from the Indian government. India said the relics were back in their “rightful home.”
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Elizabeth Bick for The New York Times
item.media:description: Some of the Piprahwa Gems, seen on display in 2023 at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

item.title: Trump Tells Russian Official to ‘Watch His Words,’ but He Bites Back Instead
item.description: The former Russian president Dmitri Medvedev offers President Trump a useful foil to criticize without rebuking Vladimir Putin, one analyst said.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: Dmitri Medvedev, Russia’s former president who now serves in a largely symbolic role, frequently wields nuclear threats against the West on social media.

item.title: Modi’s ‘True Friend’ Trump Deals India a Big Blow With Tariff Threats
item.description: India’s prime minister has made a big effort to build closer ties using his rapport with the U.S. president, but critics say he is getting little in return.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal
item.media:description: President Donald Trump and Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India at a joint news conference at the White House in February.

item.title: Witkoff Plans Visit to Gaza to See Hunger Crisis
item.description: Steve Witkoff will visit an aid distribution site in Gaza on Friday, the White House said, as anger toward Israel grows over desperation in the territory.
item.dc:creator: Natan Odenheimer
item.media:description: Steve Witkoff’s visit to Israel on Thursday is the first time he is known to have visited the country in months.

item.title: Anger Over Starvation in Gaza Leaves Israel Increasingly Isolated
item.description: Global outrage at the Netanyahu government’s actions has grown since the war began, and the suffering of children in the enclave has accelerated the disdain.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Saher Alghorra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Clamoring for aid in the Gaza City area this month. Widespread hunger has prompted increasing malnutrition and starvation.

item.title: Amid Scramble for Food, Prices in Gaza Reach Extraordinary Heights
item.description: Obtaining humanitarian aid can be difficult and dangerous, and though some essentials are available at markets, they are prohibitively expensive for many Gazans.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon and Ashley Wu

item.title: Myanmar Lifts State of Emergency, Paving the Way for Disputed Vote
item.description: The military government hopes elections can bring more international legitimacy. But the generals will still rule, and opposition groups are boycotting.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:description: Protesters clashing with security forces in Tharketa township, in Yangon, Myanmar, in 2021. The government lifted a four-year state of emergency in place since the army seized power in a coup in 2021.

item.title: Aftershocks From 8.8-Magnitude Quake Rattle North Pacific
item.description: Dozens of small earthquakes were recorded, most off the coast of Russia’s Far East. Five of them have been above magnitude 6.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse, via Russia'S Sakhalin Region Governm
item.media:description: An image released by the Sakhalin Region Government on Wednesday, showing the tsunami-hit Severo-Kurilsk on Paramushir island of Russia’s northern Kuril islands.

item.title: After Backlash, Ukraine Votes to Restore Watchdogs’ Powers
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky’s move last week to neuter two anticorruption agencies drew the country’s first street protests since Russia’s invasion.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Oleksandr Chubko
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters took to the streets of Kyiv earlier this month in response to a law signed by President Volodymyr Zelensky.

item.title: Russian Missile and Drone Attack Pummels Kyiv, Killing at Least 7
item.description: The assault, which killed at least 16 people in the Ukrainian capital, came soon after President Trump threatened new sanctions against Moscow if the bloodshed didn’t let up.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: An apartment building on Thursday after a Russian attack in Kyiv, Ukraine.

item.title: Thursday Briefing: Trump’s Steep Tariffs on Brazil
item.description: Plus, U.S.-India trade tensions.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva speaking with The New York Times on Tuesday.

item.title: Bad Weather Delays Launch of Astronauts to Space Station
item.description: For Zena Cardman, the NASA astronaut who commands the Crew-11 mission, that means another wait for her first trip to orbit.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang
item.media:description: Zena Cardman, commander of the SpaceX/NASA Crew-11 mission, arriving at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida on Saturday.

item.title: What Countries Recognize a Palestinian State: A Map
item.description: In the past week alone, three new countries have said they are ready to bestow recognition on a Palestinian state.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Wu

item.title: Canada to Recognize Palestinian State at the U.N. General Assembly
item.description: Canada joins France and Britain in taking similar steps, after months of increasing criticism of Israel by Prime Minister Mark Carney.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mark Carney of Canada has intensified his criticism of Israel over the worsening humanitarian crisis in Gaza.

item.title: Thursday Briefing: Trump’s Steep Tariffs on Brazil
item.description: Plus, the future of Mexican music.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva speaking with The New York Times on Tuesday.

item.title: Ugandan and South Sudanese Troops Exchange Fire in Border Skirmish
item.description: Eight people were reported dead after Ugandan soldiers crossed the border into South Sudan and skirmished with troops there.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson
item.media:description: Ugandan soldiers in Kampala, the capital of Uganda, in 2021. Uganda has long provided military support to the South Sudanese government.

item.title: When Earth’s Surface Shifts, the New NISAR Satellite Will See It
item.description: NISAR, built jointly by NASA and India’s space agency and launched on Wednesday, will use radar to monitor tiny changes across our planet’s land and icy regions.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang
item.media:description: The NISAR satellite, a joint mission by NASA and ISRO, lifting off from the Satish Dhawan Space Center in Sriharikota, India, on Wednesday.

item.title: Horst Mahler, 89, Dies; Voice of the German Far Left, Then the Far Right
item.description: As a young lawyer and a Communist revolutionary, he helped start the violent Red Army Faction. Later, he went to prison as a Nazi apologist and Holocaust denier.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:description: Mr. Mahler in prison in 1978. He had been convicted of crimes as a member of the radical left-wing Red Army Faction, which he had helped found.

item.title: Canada’s Measles Cases Surpass U.S., Alberta Officials Push for State of Emergency
item.description: Some doctors in Alberta have criticized officials for not declaring a health emergency in the western province where measles infections are surging.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:description: The skyline of Calgary in Alberta, where measles cases are rising.

item.title: Why Did Such a Powerful Earthquake Generate Such a Weak Tsunami?
item.description: The quake in Russia on Wednesday was among the strongest ever recorded — but in many places, the resulting wave was small.
item.dc:creator: Katrina Miller
item.media:credit: Muneyoshi Someya/Kyodo News, via Associated Press
item.media:description: People who evacuated to higher ground in Ishinomaki, Japan, watching the sea on Wednesday.

item.title: U.S. Hits Brazil With 50% Tariffs and Sanctions in Sharp Escalation
item.description: The White House hit Brazil on Wednesday with a 50 percent tariff and sanctions on a justice overseeing investigations into former President Jair Bolsonaro.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova and Jack Nicas
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva of Brazil has accused President Trump of infringing on his country’s sovereignty.

item.title: Key Hurricane-Monitoring Data Will Stay Online, Officials Say
item.description: The Department of Defense said it no longer planned to shut down a program that makes satellite data publicly available to researchers and forecasters.
item.dc:creator: Sachi Kitajima Mulkey
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: According to the Navy, the data will now remain available until the sensors stop working or until the monitoring program formally ends next year.
